title: The Era of Adherence to HIV Therapy
abstract: Editorials15 September 1998The Era of Adherence to HIV TherapyFrederick L. Altice, MD and Gerald H. Friedland, MDFrederick L. Altice, MDYale University School of Medicine; New Haven, CT 06510 and Gerald H. Friedland, MDYale University School of Medicine; New Haven, CT 06510Author, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/0003-4819-129-6-199809150-00015 SectionsAboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail The past 2 years have witnessed stunning benefits of antiretroviral therapy. Dramatic delays in HIV progression, improved survival, and decreased hospitalization for HIV-infected patients have created a renewed sense of optimism [1, 2]. For many, HIV disease has been transformed into a manageable chronic disease. However, complete enthusiasm for these recent successes has been dampened by biological, clinical, social, and economic realities that limit both access to and success of antiretroviral therapies. High HIV replication and mutation rates, varying potency of regimens, stage of HIV disease, and previous antiretroviral therapy all influence therapeutic success and failure.
